name: raredisease-family-trio
title: Rare Disease Family Trio Analysis
description: Family-based WGS for rare disease diagnosis. Analyzes proband with parents (trio) to identify de novo, inherited, and compound heterozygous variants with superior accuracy. Samplesheet format: `sample,lane,fastq_1,fastq_2,sex,phenotype`
content:
Family Trio Rare Disease Analysis

Analyze affected child (proband) with both parents for maximum diagnostic power. Trio sequencing dramatically improves variant filtering and identification of de novo mutations.

Why Trio Sequencing?

  • Higher Diagnostic Yield: 40-50% vs 25-35% for singletons
  • De Novo Detection: High confidence new mutations
  • Phase Inheritance: Determine maternal vs paternal alleles
  • Filter False Positives: Remove shared benign variants
  • Compound Heterozygotes: Validate alleles on different chromosomes
  • Inheritance Validation: Confirm mode of inheritance

Trio Analysis Advantages

Mendelian Inheritance Filtering:

  • De Novo Dominant: Present in child, absent in parents
  • Autosomal Recessive: Both parents carriers (het), child homozygous
  • Compound Heterozygous: Child has two different variants, one from each parent
  • X-Linked Recessive: Mother carrier, affected son
  • X-Linked Dominant: De novo in daughter or from affected mother

False Positive Reduction:

Trio reduces candidate variants by 90-95%

  • Remove common familial variants
  • Exclude sequencing artifacts
  • Validate rare variants through inheritance

Clinical Applications

  • Pediatric Disorders: Developmental delay, intellectual disability
  • De Novo Diseases: Epileptic encephalopathies, autism spectrum
  • Recessive Disorders: Identify compound heterozygotes
  • Consanguineous Families: Homozygosity mapping
  • Neonatal ICU: Rapid diagnosis for critically ill infants
  • Prenatal Diagnosis: Risk assessment for future pregnancies

De Novo Mutation Discovery

De novo mutations cause ~20% of severe developmental disorders

Trio sequencing identifies:

  • Coding de novo: New mutations in exons
  • Splice site de novo: Disrupt splicing
  • Regulatory de novo: Promoters, enhancers
  • Structural de novo: De novo deletions, duplications

Validation confidence: ~99% with trio vs ~80% singleton

Inheritance Pattern Analysis

  1. De Novo Variants: New in child → Dominant disease
  2. Homozygous Recessive: Both parents carriers → Recessive disease
  3. Compound Heterozygous: Different variant from each parent → Recessive disease
  4. X-Linked: From mother, affecting son
  5. Uniparental Disomy: Both alleles from one parent

Variant Prioritization

  • Inheritance Filter: Must match Mendelian pattern
  • Frequency Filter: Rare in population (gnomAD < 0.1%)
  • Pathogenicity: CADD, REVEL, SpliceAI scores
  • Gene-Phenotype Match: HPO terms matching disease genes
  • Known Pathogenic: ClinVar pathogenic/likely pathogenic
  • Loss-of-Function: Truncating variants in disease genes

Input Requirements

CSV samplesheet with proband + both parents:

  • Proband: phenotype=2 (affected)
  • Father: phenotype=1 (unaffected), paternal_id in proband row
  • Mother: phenotype=1 (unaffected), maternal_id in proband row
  • family_id: Same for all three

Key Outputs

  • De Novo VCF: High-confidence new mutations
  • Inherited VCF: Variants from parents
  • Compound Het VCF: Recessive gene pairs
  • Phased VCF: Maternal vs paternal alleles
  • Prioritized Genes: Ranked candidate genes
  • Inheritance Report: Pattern-specific findings

Perfect for: Pediatric genetics • De novo diseases • Recessive disorders • Developmental delay • Undiagnosed trios
